verses.text: The word that came to Jeremiah from the LORD in the tenth year of Zedekiah king of Judah, which was the eighteenth year of Nebuchadnezzar.
verses.comment: Dating places this prophecy at the siege of Jerusalem. Nebuchadnezzar was the Babylonian king who destroyed Jerusalem, fulfilling previous warnings from the prophets.

verses.text: At that time the army of the king of Babylon was besieging Jerusalem, and Jeremiah the prophet was confined in the courtyard of the guard, which was in the palace of the king of Judah.
verses.comment: Jeremiah was imprisoned for speaking God's word. The setting shows God's prophet suffering in fidelity, prefiguring Christ and the suffering of the faithful.

verses.text: For Zedekiah king of Judah had imprisoned him, saying, “Why do you prophesy, saying, ‘This is what the LORD says: Behold, I will give this city into the hand of the king of Babylon, and he will capture it;
verses.comment: Zedekiah resists the word of God revealed through Jeremiah. Prophetic opposition to kings recalls the independent authority of God’s-called prophets.

verses.text: and Zedekiah king of Judah will not escape out of the hand of the Chaldeans, but will surely be delivered into the hand of the king of Babylon, and will speak with him face to face and see him eye to eye.
verses.comment: God’s justice comes even to kings, and His word is always fulfilled perfectly and specifically.

verses.text: He shall lead Zedekiah to Babylon, and there he shall stay until I visit him, declares the LORD. Though you fight against the Chaldeans, you shall not succeed.”’”
verses.comment: God's sovereignty is clear: human kings cannot alter God's plans. The phrase 'until I visit him' implies future divine intervention.

verses.text: Jeremiah said, “The word of the LORD came to me:
verses.comment: Affirms Jeremiah’s prophetic mission and that God initiates communication.

verses.text: ‘Behold, Hanamel the son of Shallum your uncle will come to you and say, “Buy for yourself my field that is at Anathoth, for the right of redemption is yours to buy it.”’
verses.comment: Family land redemption was rooted in ancient Israelite law. See also Leviticus 25:25 on kinsman-redeemer obligations.

verses.text: Then Hanamel my cousin came to me in the court of the guard, just as the word of the LORD had spoken, and said to me, ‘Buy my field that is at Anathoth in the territory of Benjamin, for the right of inheritance and redemption is yours; buy it for yourself.’ Then I knew that this was the word of the LORD.
verses.comment: Jeremiah acts in faith, trusting God's word even against all visible hope, showing the trust in God’s promises that persists despite outward circumstances.

verses.text: So I bought the field at Anathoth from Hanamel, my cousin, and weighed out to him the money, seventeen shekels of silver.
verses.comment: Land purchases were made public and legal; see also Abraham’s purchase of a burial field in Genesis 23:16.

verses.text: I signed the deed, sealed it, called in witnesses, and weighed the money on the scales.
verses.comment: Public, witnessed transactions affirm the importance of accountability and tradition in God’s people.

verses.text: Then I took the deed of purchase, both the sealed copy containing the terms and conditions and the open copy;
verses.comment: Two copies for legal proof show the seriousness of the transaction, echoing Israel’s respect for covenant and law.

verses.text: and I gave the deed of purchase to Baruch the son of Neriah, in the presence of Hanamel my cousin, in the presence of the witnesses who signed the deed, and in the presence of all the Judeans who were sitting in the court of the guard.
verses.comment: Baruch was Jeremiah’s scribe. This public act points to a hope beyond the present crisis, trusting in restoration.

verses.text: I charged Baruch in their presence, saying,
verses.comment: Instructions to Baruch underscore the importance of preserving God’s word and promises for the future.

verses.text: ‘This is what the LORD of hosts, the God of Israel, says: Take these deeds, both the sealed and open copies of the deed of purchase, and put them in an earthenware jar, so that they may last for many days.’
verses.comment: Preservation of the deeds in jars is symbolic, prefiguring hope of future restoration.

verses.text: For this is what the LORD of hosts, the God of Israel, says: Houses, fields, and vineyards will again be bought in this land.
verses.comment: God promises restoration beyond captivity. Hope in the midst of judgment is a theme fulfilled in God’s greater plan.

verses.text: After I had given the deed of purchase to Baruch son of Neriah, I prayed to the LORD, saying:
verses.comment: Jeremiah responds with prayer, showing trust and seeking understanding—even when faced with confusion.

verses.text: Ah, Lord GOD! You made the heavens and the earth by Your great power and by Your outstretched arm! Nothing is too hard for You.
verses.comment: Jeremiah affirms God's omnipotence. A reminder that creation itself is foundational to God’s authority.

verses.text: You show steadfast love to thousands, but you also repay the guilt of the fathers into the laps of their children after them, O great and mighty God whose name is the LORD of hosts.
verses.comment: Jeremiah recognizes both God’s mercy and justice—characteristics that align with biblical faith about God’s nature, just and merciful.

verses.text: You are great in counsel and mighty in deed, whose eyes are open to all the ways of the children of men, rewarding each one according to his ways and according to the fruit of his deeds.
verses.comment: Classic expression of the doctrine of God’s perfect knowledge and justice. Cross reference to Jesus’ teachings on judgment in Matthew 16:27.

verses.text: You performed signs and wonders in the land of Egypt, and even to this day in Israel and among all mankind, and have made a name for yourself, as it is this day.
verses.comment: Recollection of God’s deeds connects Israel’s story to the present, inviting spiritual reflection on God’s faithfulness in history.

verses.text: You brought Your people Israel out of the land of Egypt with signs and wonders, with a mighty hand and an outstretched arm, and with great terror.
verses.comment: Passover imagery here prefigures the great deliverance in the New Covenant, linking the Old and New Testaments spiritually.

verses.text: You gave them this land, which You swore to their fathers to give them, a land flowing with milk and honey.
verses.comment: God’s faithfulness ensures fulfillment of His promises, foreshadowing the inheritance of all who remain faithful.

verses.text: Yet they did not obey Your voice or walk in Your law. They did nothing of all that You commanded them to do. Therefore, You have brought all this disaster upon them.
verses.comment: Disobedience brings judgment, a recurring biblical theme. Christ fulfills and transforms the law so that by grace and faith in Him, one can participate in God’s promises.

verses.text: See how the siege mounds have come up to the city to capture it. Because of sword, famine, and plague, the city is given into the hand of the Chaldeans who fight against it. What You spoke has come to pass, and behold, You see it.
verses.comment: God’s warnings are never empty threats; fulfillment of prophecy shows both His justice and reliability.

verses.text: Yet, O Lord GOD, You say to me, ‘Buy the field for money and call in witnesses’—though the city is given into the hand of the Chaldeans.”
verses.comment: Jeremiah’s faith is tested—called to hope while Israel faces judgment. Purchasing land demonstrates trust in God’s plan beyond visible realities.

verses.text: Then the word of the LORD came to Jeremiah:
verses.comment: God responds directly to His prophet in intimate communion, stressed throughout biblical traditions as a model for all believers.

verses.text: Behold, I am the LORD, the God of all flesh; is anything too hard for Me?
verses.comment: Echoing God's promise to Abraham, this reveals the unchangeable nature of God’s power and plans. Ties directly to gospel proclamations of God's power.

verses.text: Therefore thus says the LORD: Behold, I am giving this city into the hand of the Chaldeans and into the hand of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, and he shall take it.
verses.comment: Repeated warning of judgment, confirming God’s word will be fulfilled exactly, no matter worldly resistance.

verses.text: The Chaldeans who are fighting against this city shall come and set this city on fire and burn it, together with the houses on whose roofs offerings have been made to Baal and drink offerings have been poured out to other gods, to provoke Me to anger.
verses.comment: Destruction is linked to Israel's idolatry. The mention of rooftops underscores the pervasiveness of their false worship.

verses.text: For the children of Israel and the children of Judah have done nothing but evil in My sight from their youth. For the children of Israel have continually provoked Me to anger by the works of their hands, declares the LORD.
verses.comment: Collective guilt is pronounced, emphasizing humanity’s deep need for redemption—a theme answered in Christ’s atonement.

verses.text: For this city has aroused My anger and My wrath from the day it was built to this day, so that I must remove it from My sight,
verses.comment: Jerusalem’s centrality is stressed, yet its judgment will lead to a future purification and restoration.

verses.text: because of all the evil of the children of Israel and the children of Judah that they did to provoke Me to anger— they, their kings, their officials, their priests, their prophets, the men of Judah and the inhabitants of Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Judgment includes all classes of society, even priests and prophets, underscoring the necessity of true, faithful leadership and mediation.

verses.text: They have turned to Me their back and not their face. Though I taught them persistently, rising up early and teaching them, yet they would not listen and receive instruction.
verses.comment: Persistent teaching by God evokes the patient teaching office found in the apostolic church, continuing through authoritative succession.

verses.text: They have set up their abominations in the house that is called by My name, to defile it.
verses.comment: False worship in the temple itself emphasizes the depth of Judah's apostasy, contrasting with Christ’s cleansing of the temple (see John 2:13-17).

verses.text: They built the high places of Baal in the Valley of Ben-hinnom, to make their sons and daughters pass through the fire to Molech, though I did not command them, nor did it enter my mind that they should do this abomination, to cause Judah to sin.
verses.comment: Child sacrifice was a horrific pagan practice totally condemned by God.

verses.text: Now therefore, thus says the LORD, the God of Israel, concerning this city of which you say, 'It is given into the hand of the king of Babylon by sword, by famine, and by plague:'
verses.comment: God repeats His sentence to remind Jeremiah and the people that the judgment is not accidental, but just.

verses.text: Behold, I will gather them from all the lands to which I have driven them in My anger, My wrath, and My great indignation. I will bring them back to this place, and I will make them dwell in safety.
verses.comment: God promises future restoration—gathering dispersed people is a theme fulfilled spiritually in the unity of the Church.

verses.text: They shall be My people, and I will be their God.
verses.comment: A key covenant formula, fulfilled in the new covenant through Christ. The spiritual family of God carries out this reality.

verses.text: I will give them one heart and one way, that they may fear Me always, for their own good and for the good of their children after them.
verses.comment: God promises supernatural unity—a foreshadowing of Christ’s prayer for the unity of all believers (see John 17:21).

verses.text: I will make with them an everlasting covenant, that I will not turn away from doing good to them. And I will put My fear in their hearts, so that they will never turn away from Me.
verses.comment: Here the new and everlasting covenant is prophesied—a deeper spiritual transformation is promised and realized ultimately in Christ.

verses.text: I will rejoice in doing them good, and I will plant them in this land in faithfulness, with all My heart and all My soul.
verses.comment: God’s love is expressed in strong, personal terms. The image of planting evokes stability and fruitfulness.

verses.text: For this is what the LORD says: Just as I have brought all this great evil upon this people, so I will bring upon them all the good that I promise them.
verses.comment: God’s promises will never fail—His mercy will overflow once justice is complete.

verses.text: Fields will be bought in this land of which you are saying, ‘It is a desolation, without man or beast. It is given into the hand of the Chaldeans.’
verses.comment: Repeat of land promise, showing God’s power to restore the broken. Hope is never lost when rooted in God.

verses.text: Fields will be bought for silver, and deeds will be signed and sealed and witnessed, in the land of Benjamin, in the places around Jerusalem, and in the cities of Judah, in the cities of the hill country, in the cities of the Shephelah, and in the cities of the Negev; for I will restore their fortunes, declares the LORD.”
verses.comment: The restoration covers all regions—signifying total renewal. God’s promise encompasses all His people, and authentic hope in God is always tangible and historical. This points spiritually ahead to the unity and renewal found only in faithfully receiving God’s covenant blessings.
